pageData.text: The scientific workflow requires that a scientist minimizes the potential for , both from and to themselves, during an experiment. This contamination can potentially be harmful to the individual performing the experiment and their environment. The contamination may also introduce unknown variables into the experiment, making it harder to distinguish the actual results from potential outside influences. In order to minimize contamination, personal protective equipment should be worn when needed and proper hand washing techniques should be practiced at all times.

pageData.text: Hand hygiene is extremely important for not only conducting laboratory activities safely, but also maintaining the health of ourselves and our loved ones. One gram of human feces – a paperclip’s worth – contains one trillion germs<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Washing your hands properly after using the restroom, changing a diaper, or touching public surfaces can greatly reduce the spread of germs from feces, which are a major source of germs that cause diarrheal diseases. If everyone in the world routinely washed their hands, we could prevent 1 million deaths a year<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>. Hand sanitizer is a useful hand hygiene tool but should not replace thorough hand washing.  They do not eliminate all types of germs, nor are they guaranteed to remove other kinds of hand contaminants such as pesticides or heavy metals<sup class='bodySupscript'>3</sup>. Keeping hand sanitizer nearby is handy in a pinch, but whenever possible, wash your hands.

1Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (10 September 2020). Show Me the Science – Why Wash Your Hands? CDC.
https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/why-handwashing.html

2Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (15 June 2022). Hygiene Fast Facts. CDC.
https://www.cdc.gov/hygiene/fast-facts.html

3Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (15 June 2022). Keeping Hands Clean. CDC.
https://www.cdc.gov/hygiene/personal-hygiene/hands.html

pageData.desc: Soapy hands clasped together over a sink.
pageData.altText: Soapy hands clasped together over a sink.

pageData.text: In a scientific setting we sometimes work with potentially hazardous chemicals, microbes, or fluids from lab specimens. Proper <button class='glossary-text'>sanitization</button>  (cleaning or disinfection) will minimize the risk of <button class='glossary-text'>contamination</button> (the presence of undesirable substances or microbes).

It is also possible to introduce an outside variable from your environment into your experiment. contamination makes it more difficult to obtain consistent results and may even produce false results. Potential contamination sources include anything you have touched that might still be on your hands. It can be food products, hair and dander from humans and animals, or even naturally occurring bacteria from your skin. Figure 1 shows microbes cultured from the surface of a cell phone.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Various colonies of microbial growth on an agar plate.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Various colonies of microbial growth on an agar plate.

pageData.text: All these elements can introduce an unknown factor or variable to the experiment, which makes it difficult to obtain accurate, interpretable results. In order to reduce these outside factors you should sanitize your hands before and after the experiments as well as any time you take a break or touch anything outside the experiment.

For instance, when you perform a dissection, or work with a microbial culture, you will sometimes need to use a camera or mobile device to document your work. If you will need to take photos frequently, the device may be packaged in a clear, resealable plastic bag. Likewise, if you are carrying out a timed procedure and need to use a mobile device as a timer, seal the device in a clear plastic bag. You should thoroughly wash your hands before and after handling the device.

In this laboratory activity, we are using a product containing tiny particles that fluoresce or glow under ultraviolet (UV) light. The product is called Glo Germ™. These particles stick to your skin; however, they can be washed away just like actual microbes. You will apply Glo Germ™ to your hands and then wash them. Afterward, you will perform a series of steps that simulate common laboratory procedures in which contamination could occur. When you touch objects while you have Glo Germ™ on your hand, the particles transfer to the object you are handling. You can track Glo Germ™ “contamination” using a small UV light source. This investigation demonstrates how easily contamination can occur and shows the proper ways to eliminate possible contamination.

pageData.question: How will you observe contamination and particle transfer in this investigation?

options.text: Use UV light to track Glo Germ™ transfer from your hands to other surfaces.
Track the average number of days you are ill over the course of 30 days.
Culture microbes from your hands before and after handwashing.
Culture microbes swabbed from household surfaces before and after disinfection.
Use UV light to observe microbes on your hands before and after handwashing.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this laboratory activity, we are using a product containing tiny particles that fluoresce, or glow, under ultraviolet (UV) or black light. The product is called Glo Germ™. These particles stick to your skin; however, they can be washed off by effective hand washing, just like actual bacteria can. You will perform normal laboratory steps and track any “contamination” with the UV light. When you touch objects while you have Glo Germ™ on your hand, the particles transfer to the object you are handling.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Arange the materials and label the test tubes. Don your personal protective equipment (PPE). Perform a hand wash treatment. In the no wash treatment, apply Glo Germ then do not wash your hands. In the quick wash treatment, quickly wash and dry your hands. In the good wash treatment, reapply the Glo Germ then wash your hands thoroughly. After the wash treatment, transfer water to test tubes using a pipet. Turn off the lights and examine the laboratory area with a black light. Record the number of glowing contamination spots. Perform all three hand wash treatments.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement investigation kit for Hand Washing Techniques, item number 580700, can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
This investigation requires protective eyewear and a lab apron or lab coat.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Activity sections.
Refer to your instructions and videos on safe laboratory practices before beginning this investigation.

• The Glo Germ™ in this kit is not for human consumption. Keep out of reach of children and pets.
  • Do not look directly into the ultraviolet light. This can damage the eyes.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area and all lab equipment with soap and water after completing the investigation.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements about contamination is correct?

options.text: Contamination makes it more difficult to obtain consistent results and may even produce false results.
Potential contamination sources only include things that you are directly in contact with.
Proper sanitary lab practices completely remove the risk of contamination.
Contaminants are transmitted only by airborne particles.
Contamination does not occur easily.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following would be LEAST likely to result in contamination?

options.text: washing your hands properly before and after lab work
eating while performing an experiment
scratching your head while performing an experiment
touching your face while performing an experiment
disinfecting your gloves after completing an experiment

Wipe the device with disinfectant solution before and after starting the investigation.
Take off your gloves when using the device during the investigation.
Keep your gloves on when using the device during the investigation.
Place the device in a well-ventilated area during the investigation.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Clean the work area. Make sure the work area is large enough for all three of the experimental groups described in the Activity section.
Read the instructions.
Obtain all materials.

In this investigation, you will observe the effects of various degrees of handwashing on the <button class='glossary-text'>contamination</button> of your laboratory environment. You will apply Glo Germ™ to your hands, then either not wash, wash quickly, or wash thoroughly your hands. After performing a basic laboratory technique, you will observe the resulting contamination from your hands using a black light (UV light) and determine the effects of thorough hand washing.

Open up the investigation materials and place the contents on a flat surface. Divide the tubes, transfer pipettes, and cardboard test tube racks into three separate groups with two tubes, one transfer pipette, and one tube rack in each group. Fill the beaker with tap water.
Use the grease pencil to label the two tubes in one of the groups No wash, the two tubes in the second group Quick wash, and the last two tubes Good wash.
Put on your PPE (goggles, lab apron or lab coat).
Shake the bottle of Glo Germ™ well.

Apply a quarter-sized amount of Glo Germ™ to the palm of your hand and rub your hands together. Make sure to get in between your fingers and onto the back of your hands. Take care not to let the Glo Germ™ contact your clothes or any other cloth, as staining may occur.
Take a transfer pipette and transfer 3 mL of tap water from the beaker to a test tube in the No wash box. Repeat with the second test tube in this group and the same pipette.
Turn off the light or make the area as dark as possible without compromising your safety.

Use the ultraviolet light to examine your work area. Be sure to check your lab apron or lab coat and the surrounding area. The “” should light up under the ultraviolet light. Observe the extent of your “contamination.”
Record the number of glowing “contamination” spots from each experiment in Data Table 1. Include spots on the pipette, the tubes themselves, the tube rack, and the No wash part of the work area.
Quickly wash your hands with soap and rinse, as most of us normally do on a routine basis.
Take the transfer pipette from the Quick wash group and transfer 3 mL of tap water from the beaker to a test tube. Repeat for the second test tube in the group with the same pipette.
Turn off the light or make the area as dark as possible.
Use the ultraviolet light to examine the sink where you washed your hands and observe the <button class='glossary-text'>contamination</button>.
Record the number of glowing “contamination” spots in Data Table 1. Include spots on the pipette, the tubes themselves, the tube rack, and the Quick wash part of the work area.

Optional step: If you have someone else in your household, have them wash their hands in the same sink you used to rinse your hands. Have them walk around the house without watching them. After a few minutes, try to follow their movements with the ultraviolet light. You should see a glow on everything they touched after they washed their hands. Make sure to note these locations and clean them with soap and water or household cleaner after you have finished the entire investigation.

typeBefore.title: Part III. Washing techniques (9 steps)
typeBefore.text: Before proceeding with this part of the activity, watch the video on proper handwashing technique.

pageData.text: Make sure your hands are well in front of your body and over the sink. Rinse your hands with your fingers pointing downwards.
Apply liquid soap to your hands. To avoid contaminating the soap dispenser, use a paper towel to push the plunger.

Massage the soap thoroughly into your hands. Take care to keep your hands pointed downwards, away from your body and towards the sink. Make sure to get the back of your hands and between your fingers.
After thoroughly washing your hands, use the brush to clean underneath each of your nails. Rinse well and dry your hands from the wrist down with a paper towel.
Turn off the light or make the area as dark as possible.
Check your hand washing progress with the ultraviolet light.
Remove all traces of the Glo Germ™ by washing and scrubbing those areas still glowing under the ultraviolet light.
Dry your hands from the wrist down with a paper towel. Check the sink and surrounding areas for any <button class='glossary-text'>contamination</button>.
Use soap to remove all traces of contamination. Remember to clean the ultraviolet light itself with a damp paper towel.
Reapply Glo Germ™ as described in Part I, steps 4 and 5.
Wash your hands as described in Part III. Make sure you only touch the faucet with a paper towel. Use a different paper towel to dry your hands and turn the faucet off.
Take a transfer pipette from the Good wash group and transfer 3 mL of tap water from the beaker to a test tube. Repeat for the second test tube in the group with the same pipette.
Turn off the light or make the area as dark as possible.
Use the ultraviolet light to examine your work area.
Record the number of glowing spots from each experiment in Data Table 1. Include spots on the pipette, the tubes themselves, the tube rack, and the Good wash part of the work area.
Note the difference between the No wash, Quick wash, and Good wash data.

text: Dispose of activity waste, including used pipettes, cardboard test tube racks, and paper towels in the household trash.
Discard the water in the sink. Rinse the beaker, test tubes, and brush in the sink. Dry and return them to your lab kit for later use.
Clean the work area with soap and water, and dry with paper towels.
Check all areas with the ultraviolet light. Make sure to locate and clean all the surfaces you see with Glo Germ™ “<button class='glossary-text'>contamination</button>.”

text: What was the main difference you saw between your routine hand washing technique and the “Good wash” from the manual?
Which part of your hands did you find the most difficult to clean?
When examining your lab coat or lab apron after the Quick wash, did you see small spots of “contamination”? If so, how can you explain that?
